description.text: Also available on Shapeways: http://shpws.me/Fbn5 This is an enclosure for the FG085 Function Generator Kit. When assembled, the kit has exposed sides and I wanted them to be covered to avoid any short circuits or debris from causing problems. There are other things out there (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74152 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:521812 thank you for the inspiration) that look great, but just didn't work for me. I did not want to have to manually drill out holes to access the power and USB or tape two pieces of plastic together. Therefore, I designed this from the build plate up to be a single piece that just works and fits the FG085 perfectly.

Orient the file so that the open ends are in the vertical axis.  I printed with 1 wall, 10% infill and no support material and it seems to be fine.  Took 2 hours on a Rep 2.  
Once printed, simply remove the back panel of the FG085, slide this object over the PCB up to the front panel (ensuring proper orientation so that the USB and Power holes line up properly), and then re-attach the back panel.

comments.text: Works great! Only wish is that the "depth" of the enclosure was a little wider.. 1mm?. The FG085 wiggles front to back around 0.5mm.  1mm wider and the screws would hold the plexi tight within the enclosure.
comments.author: kallisti5

title: One Print Sunglasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These sunglasses you can print out in one print job! The hinges are built into the part, and all you need to do is place some old sunglasses lenses from an old pair of frames you dont want anymore into the print as it's printing. I've also left holes in the centers of each of the side pieces so that you can slide 1/16 inch steel rod through the middle to make them stronger! Check out my 3D printing blog at printeraction.wordpress.com; the vlog for this video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aF3cwmVBWxE&feature=youtu.be

Once the printer starts to print the overhangs above the lens cavity, place the lenses into the cavities so that they can be constrained and the print can complete over them.  
To add strength to the sides of your frames, slide steel rods no larger than 3.5 inches into the holes in the center of the sides of the glasses once they are tall enough to add a steel core to the center, making the part stronger!

comments.text: well done!

title: mini toggle switch mounting bracket.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This bracket was drawn up to fit a small toggle switch with a housing about 13mm X 13mm square and a 6mm(ish) post. This mount was also designed with a small cable tie strain relief (see pics) which should resist moderate accidental pulling and snagging. This is the kind of mini toggle used by hobbyists, model train tinkerers and miscellaneous electrical whos-a-whatsers.

comments.text: Thanks for your work!  I use this kind of switch in all of my electronics projects.  The post hole is larger than needed for a 6mm post, but, better bigger than having to drill out if your printer makes "undersize" which my Da Vinci tends to do.  Your design captures and centers the switch so the oversize hole is a non-issue.  It accommodates the double-pole version easily.
comments.author: gwlinn

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. I am getting quite a lot of satisfaction that people are finding this useful.  My sentiments exactly about the slightly oversized hole. I think most printers have a tendency to print tight dimensions on inside corners and inside diameters. I've noticed that this seems to be more of an issue at cooler print temps when slightly "gooier" or partially solidified plastics have a greater tendency to be drawn toward the inside of the circular print path. (more of a guess than real science though) But why not... if the design will permit a bit of slop in these areas that its simply best to leave a bit of extra room.
comments.author: gwlinn

This is a custom built version of the latest ReplicatorG (24) that includes to option to home your Makerbot using only one GCode (M138). It also includes a ready to use custom-built firmware for both the Thingomatic and the Cupcake that stores all of the data needed to home the Makerbot, right on the Makerbot! In permanent EEPROM memory! This means that one no longer has to re-slice all of their model STL files just to fix their homing routine! Just run through the GUI based setup process again (located in the control panel) to recalibrate your homing position and the Makerbot should start every print from its new home location without any re-skeining. In addition to being easier to use and modify than messing around with the old homing routine in the Start.txt file, opens up the possibility of using the same Start.txt file for multiple bots (Yay botfarming!) If you're curious about the code involved in this script. You can find the sourcecode in my Github Repos (with a pending pull to the ReplicatorG and MB firmware trunk)
Here: git://github.com/xtremd/ReplicatorG.git And here for the custom Makerbot firmware: git://github.com/xtremd/Xtremd.git Disclaimer: This homing routine does an intricate dance designed to keep nozzle crashing possibilities to a minimum. It should always work but sometimes (usually due to user error/misread instructions/badly coded start.gcode/Evil Gremlins) very bad things can happen. Please be careful when first using this! I am in no way responsible for your bot driving a very hot nozzle through its build platform due to some user error or any other horrible train-wreck set of circumstances!! Sorry that sounded so much like a TV infomercial. Happy Hacking! :)

• Download the prebuilt ReplicatorG application for your operating system from the files below.

  • Upload the new firmware using the "Upload new firmware..." selection under the "Machine" Menu. (You need to upload both the extruder FW and the motherboard FW)

  • Go to the controlpanel and select the Automatic Homing -> Setup Automatic Homing menue item. Follow the instructions. You only have to do this once. Ever.

  • Check that your Start.gcode files have chunk of code that looks like this:
    ( begin homing )
    M138 (Go Home!)
    ( end homing )
    • If you dont have it, add it!

  • Re-Slice everything to add the M138 code. Note: Once the M138 code has been added and skeined into the gcode there is no longer any need to re-skein a file just to change its homing settings; Just run the Automatic Homing -> Setup Automatic Homing menue item from the control panel and the new settings will automatically take effect.

  • Watch your bot home and print autonomously! IMPORTANT NOTE: Keep your finger on the power switch the first time that your bot is homing until you know that you have calibrated it correctly! A sad but delicious Swiss cheese build platform could result if you are not careful with the setup!

comments.text: Damn, I hate Swiss cheese!  The only good thing the Swiss came out with is their Army knife... but I have 2 or 3 Gerber knives that have really made the Swiss look like group of lazy people.  However, I have to admit that the Swiss Army knife (even though they don't really have an Army, which is a hard thing to grasp for a former Marine) pretty much spawned the evolution of kinives such as the Leatherman and the Gerber knives I own now.
comments.author: clintkc

comments.text: HURRAY!!! Just what I've been looking for!  I've finally come to the conclusion that it's much easier to print my "things" from the SD card, rathter than from my old laptop.  I only use the laptop to set the "HOME" position before each print.  I'm using Jetty's COMPLETELY AWESOME firmware for the Gen-4 interface, and don't know how your update will interfere with Jetty's "The Lord of the Thing" interface... LOL.  I've tried to print objects completely independent of my laptop (using the homing routine in Gcode), bjut it always seems to start printing about 1/2" about my HBP.   I've always deleted the "homing" section of my Gcode, because it has never worked for my ToM.  I pre-heat my machine and start my files from the SD card (after making sure to use my laptop to set all axes to the "HOME" position).  Otherwise, I would be dealing with a lot of Gcode commands that I haven't quite learned yet,

comments.text: I modded the design to include a slightly flared base which helps keep it stable, and four circular indents for AUS $1.60 worth of 10c pieces to add a bit of weight. I haven't glued the coins in yet - I need to print some circular covers for the holes - but just testing the weight with the coins gives enough mass to hold a ball of yarn about 25-30g. That's about 90m of four-ply, which just fits in the bowl. I printed mine at 97.5% full size so it would fit on my print bed with an ooze-wall as I was doing a two-colour print. I gave the inside a light sand with P180 abrasive paper and finished it with 1200 grit wet-and-dry abrasive paper.

comments.text:
Looking at this I have a few questions:
1) The print orientation - Did you print upside down?
2) The finish - The feature picture has obviously either been clear coated with silicone or polyurethane or is ABS that been through some type of acetone finishing, however, the green one looks to have much less finishing done to it and I was wondering how the finish on the green one effects the user's ability to yarn without snagging?
3) Infill - Seems to me ( I don't do anything with yarn mind you) that this bowl would maybe need to be at least a couple pounds. What infill percentage was used to get the bowl to enough mass to not just slide all over the place while the user is pulling the yarn through the hole?

author: JuanVL

title: Extra degree of freedom for modular robotics REPY-2.0 module

description.text:
Little extra for the REPY-2.0 mechanical module for modular robotics. Here are some videos about the added funcionality:
http://youtu.be/H3VW2Z-FlzI
http://youtu.be/l1j4gek27yQ Here, more info about the REPY (the version previous to the 2.0):
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13442
http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=M%C3%B3dulos_REPY-1 And, finally, the REPY-2.0 repository on github (this object is in the 'experimental' branch, and for a good reason):
https://github.com/David-Estevez/REPY-2.0 This thing, and the REPY-2.0, have been created with the Object-Oriented Mechanics Library (OOML):
http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php?id=start

This thing is highly experimental. Print it under your own risk

  • This thing is supposed to work with the REPY-2.0, previous versions of the REPY module are not tested.

  • A TowerPro SG90 mini servo is required.

• Print both parts
  • File and sand them until the servo and servo horn fits in both part. Extensive filing and sanding may be required.
  • Assemble it. The part with the horn should be attached to the lower part of the REPY module and the part with the servo should be attached to the upper part of the REPY module. Partial disassembly of the REPY module may be required.

The bolts attaching the metal plate to the upgrade are countersunk so they sit flush, increasing printing area to near full. Parts that it requires are listed below: 15x 20mm M3 Bolt
4x 25mm Countersink M3 Bolt
4x M3 Nuts
GT2 Timing Belt
2 Zipties
4 Springs from Clicky Pens

The 4 counter sink bolts are used for bed leveling in conjunction with the springs from the clicky pen. The final 20mm M3 bolt is used to trigger the X end stop. The rest is pretty self explanatory when looking at the pictures.

title: FFF 3D-printable Utah Teapot with separate lid

description.text:
This version of the very famous Utah teapot is adapted to be 3D printable on an FFF 3D printer. The model is made of two parts, the body and the lid as a separate item. In contrast to the original version this teapot has an inside and working spout! The teapot can be 3D-printed in one go without need of any support. The only exception is the built-in webbed support for the upper part of the handle. This can be easily removed with a sharp knife.
The original size of the model in the STL file is 180 mm from the back part of the handle to the front of the spout. It can be scaled larger and smaller. If you want to make it smaller, please make the webbed support thicker so it maintains roughly 0.5 mm in thickness.
The model in the image was 3D-printed with PLA plastic filament on a The Utah Teapot was made 38 years ago by Martin Newell back at the University of Utah. It has become an icon for computer graphics since then and can be found in 3D software and movies. Read more about it at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utah_teapot By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

The following files are provided for download
  • Original Rhino 3D file
  • STEP file
  • STL file with body and lid ready for 3D printing
  • netfabb scene file with dimensions
    Use a sharp knife to remove the thin support material inside the teapot's handle.

title: The Communist Laser-Cut Dual Bookbinding Jig

description.text:
True glastnost, my comrades!  Basement publishing for all your derisive works!
All joking aside, the internet is amazing for archiving old, out of copyright pdfs.  But nothing beats sitting down with a real physical book, so I decided to start binding my own.
I call this jig the communist bookbinding jig because all your books are going to look pretty much the same - sharp, square, spartan little beaters that can be read and read, folded and abused with wild abandon - hey, you can always crank out another copy!
The jig is 2-sided and sized for US paper:  The first side aligns a full 8.5 x 11 sheet, the other side aligns a half-sheet (8.5 x 5.5).  Adobe reader is great at paginating your pdf (booklet mode) so half-sheets can be easily chopped and stacked and your pages end up in the right order.
This jig is cut from 6mm Baltic Birch plywood, and requires two each of 4" x 1/4" carriage bolts, washers, and wingnuts for the clamps, and wood glue to assemble.  The length of the carriage bolts is negotiable if you plan to make thinner or thicker books.  Each side will hold a max of about 400 or so pages, giving up to an 800 page book when printed double sided.
I use this jig for binding printed pdf's, as well as compiling volumes of kid art into nice manageable archives for later reminiscence.  We're probably up to volume 5 or 6 of kid art, we just can't bear to throw it away!!
As far as assembly goes: Check out the pdf first - the green shapes go on the bottom side (half-size jig) and the black shapes are the top side (full size jig).  Some extra green pieces are added to the periphery to act as a stable platform when using the top side, and the top-side box acts as a vertical stand to keep everything upright as the glue dries.  
There is one clamp bar each for top and bottom so you can really crank the binding down tight.  You will note the bottom clamp bar has square cutouts to fit the carriage bolt head.  
The instructions for binding are simple:  Square up your pages in the jig, and gently tighten the clamp bars to bring the pages together.  Thoroughly paint the spine with the glue of your choosing, wait 10 minutes to let it soak a bit and then crank the clamps down tight to form the spine.  Leave it sit until dry, and add a cover.
With regards to binding:  I've gotten good results with Aileen's Tacky glue, as well as strong but ugly/foamy/lumpy results from gorilla glue.    And you'll notice I use both blue tape and plastic wrap to keep from gluing my book to the jig - consider it!
There is a wealth of information and opinions on bookbinding easily available online - I'm certainly no expert.  You'll find lots of discussions on glues, cover options, to all sorts of techniques.  Search and enjoy your foray into home publishing!

title: Prusa i3 Z End-Stop mount [Folger Tech]

description.text:
Designed on / for my Folger Tech Prusa i3. I found the mount that came with the kit kept sliding - or would break if I tighetened it too much. Take a look at all the pictures, and maximize them, as they are cut off when in web page view. 2015-06-12 Realized never had any side shots - they have been added. Also a side view video is at http://youtu.be/dZHDUUFaER8 This design mounts to the Z stepper through the acrylic with some extra screws I had left after the kit was assembled. I just replaced the short ones that screwed into the motors with longer ones to hold it in place. Changes were made to keep the guides from flopping around. I think this setup is where I will leave it, as it is working well.
The square guides keep the adjustable piece in the base, while the upside-down screw allows for fine tuning of the height of the end stop. While they aren't necessarily required, slots were designed in to hold nuts, but the screws were a perfect fit that they didn't need it. The cutout in the adjustable mount is space for the solders that stick through on the back of the end-stop. Use care when handling the guide part. I have broken the guides a few times (superglue works wonders). OpenSCAD files are included if you so choose to play.

Take a look at all the pictures, and maximize them, as they are cut off when in web page view.  
The holes are setup so that any screw with a shaft diameter around 3mm (same as those that came in my Folger Tech kit) will work. I did use a 4-40x3/4 screw for adjusting the height of the end stop, as I was out of spares from my kit, and that was the smallest metric Home Depot seems to carry without being a special order.  
Slide the mounting screws down the square guide shafts (it's a tight fit) and use a small screwdriver to screw them in (see the pic).  I suggest pre-threading the height adjustment screw before mounting the part to the printer.  The holes for mounting are slightly off centre, and should be put closer to the printer (facing in).  This was done so the plastic wouldn't interfere with the Z drive.  
While I have 1 picture showing the End-Stop facing out, I don't believe it will make contact there.  Ensure it is facing in.  
The OpenSCAD is included, feel free to adjust and improve.

comments.text: Just added some pics and a video, hope that helps.  The end stop mounts on the side of the z drive furthest from the acrylic.  Also, the mount holes are offset slightly to put some added space between the mount and the z connector - which also creates the space needed for the stop itself.  Make sure it is rotated the right way to get the extra distance.

comments.text: Make sure you use full view on the images, otherwise, parts are cut off, and you won't get the full effect.  It's all in the instruction (I tried to reword it to make it clearer), but it uses an upside down machine screw to adjust the height of the upper part.  Nothing else required.  By screwing it in further you will adjust the stop higher, as the end stop is mounted to the upper portion. This is the first truncation of the 4D Simplex.  It is a perspective view with one of the tetrahedral cells as the closest cell.  It is made from 5 tetrahedra and 5 truncated tetrahedra.

comments.text: How did you go about designing this? What software did you use? I am trying to design an icosahedron with a similar wire frame design.
comments.author: leyonrohr

comments.text: At the time I was designing this I used Mathematica for all my designs.  Everything was done as a parametric surface.  Now I would use OpenScad.  Put a sphere anywhere you want a vertex. Then take the "hull()" of each pair of spheres where you want an edge.  This is reasonably easy to accomplish by writing a module that acts like "polyhedron()."  It takes two lists as inputs.  The first is a list of the coordinates of the vertices.  The second is a list of the pairs that get connected.  Then a "for()" loop can do all of the hulls in one statement.

title: Art Project: Have your 3D Model displayed in an Art Gallery

description.text:
Participate in a Crowd-Sourced Art Project to be displayed in a Art Gallery in Victoria BC Canada!  
For this art project, I am crowd sourcing 3D models to be printed in red ABS and displayed on shelves on a wall in a grid pattern at an art gallery in Victoria BC. The exhibition is in early May. The concept involves the editing of the cube model on this site into whatever you like so long as it is printable and meets the Parameters specified below. I won't make any content judgements, only technical (manufacturing) judgements, so upload whatever you like and it will be displayed in the gallery setting. The printed models may be given away for free during the exhibition and replaced by new prints of your model. Photos will be posted to this site after the exhibition. Please note that I won't be selling any of these models or making any profit from this process.  
Theory:  
Is this really art? That is one topic being explored here. In this piece, roles are being shifted with the artist as the manufactor  and the art content being sourced from all of you. It speaks to the new relationship we have with information, ownership and creativity thanks to the growth of the digital age. It seems clear that 3D printing has the potential to change the relationship that we have with precious objects and sculpture as well as the manufacturing process. There are parallels to be drawn with the music industry and the effect that cheap and easy-to-use professional recording software and hardware has had on the creation of music.

Instructions: 1) Edit the 10cm3 Cube model using Google Sketchup (.SKP) or your favourite STL compatible modelling program.
2) Send it back to me as an .STL or .SKP using https://dbinbox.com/samfielder. Parameters: (If these aren't met then the design may not be selected) -You must edit the original model. No pasting your own design (honour system).
-Must fit into my print bed size 20cm x 20cm x 20cm.
-Must be reasonably easy to print without loads of overhangs and such. I don't want to edit models, unless its just to cut it in two halves to print and glue back together.
-It must sit still without rolling. Filtering Process: First 25 submissions will be selected so long as they meet the Parameters listed above. If a lot more submissions are received, the project may be expanded to include more than 25.

This is the metric version of my "impossible bolt": http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:674972 The impossible bolt demonstrates a technique called "co-processing", where one can modify a 3D printed part as it is being printed. It's also a fun 3D printed object to trick your friends with! This only has the file for the bolt and uses an M12-1.75 nut.
Check out my blog: https://printeraction.wordpress.com/
and my vlog about it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGW6zMLpge8&feature=youtu.be

When the bolt is about halfway printed, pause the print and screw an M12-1.75 nut onto the bolt.  
The MakerBot Replicator 2s lower their build plates when you select "change filament". If you have a different printer, it would be usefule to print two bolts, and screw the nut onto one of them while paused over the other.

title: Mac pro G5  DVD drive enclosure

description.text:
Mac pro G5 DVD drive enclosure I loved the elegant lines of this Mac Pro and I always thought it would be cool to make a 'mini' enclosure for the original Mac mini.
But before I do that I thought I try the idea by using it as a enclosure for my DVD burner I bought on Ebay. Its made in two parts, one is the body, the other the lid to be glued on the lid of the DVD burner. It just finished 3D printing and assemblying so i will clean it up before posting the final photos. PLEASE PRINT PHOTOS WHEN YOU HAVE MADE ONE I hope you enjoy this and let me know if anyone is interested one for the mac mini? Check my other Apple related designs to suit iphones and ipad minis Ten years ago, Apple introduced the Power Macintosh G5, the first of a new generation of Macs based on IBM’s PowerPC G5 architecture. Unveiled by Steve Jobs during the 2003 World Wide Developer’s Conference.
Benj Edwards , Macworld

The body and the lid are in one file side by side.
Print it then insert your DVD burner in the slot provided.
I have allowed extra room to suit most sizes
I will post the maximum dimensions the DVD burner can be if you want. then insert the burner, and add support where required with foam or anything that will NOT bend the frame of the burner or it will not open smoothly anymore. use double sided tape to put on the mac lid onto the DVD burner lid, making sure the door closes and you have clearances all round. glue everything (make sure you glue the lid with the DVD lid open in case you spill glue and the mechanism will never open again. enjoy.

title: REAR LENS CAP for SONY E MOUNT LENSES (mirrorless digital camera A7, NEX, etc)

description.text:
Screws onto the back of E Mount lenses, (the side facing the camera) 2 Refined designs included (heavy duty / normal) Improvements: 'Graduated Sloped Latches / ledges' means Smooth and secure tightening even on low end low resolution printers. it will work just fine on 0.15mm layer height even on cheap 3D printers. (IMPORTANT: to print the 45 Degrees slopes, Your 'Layer height' must be Less than half the width of your nozzle, that way the extruded plastic 'won't 'fall off the clif' so to speak.. Mesh has been checked and cleared of all errors.
Slices without issues. Locks and tightens smoothly and nicely.
The "E MOUNT" Text Indentation stamp is there to collect sand and dirt that would otherwise scratch lens when you turn / twist it. So any dirt goes there rather than rub against your lens.
Comes in 2 designs:
1)High impact double layer and thick wall for expensive lenses and 2)more economical single wall normal version. TIP: Don't Print in black, Only silly manufacturers do that.
Print in White / bright colours so you can see it clearly and don't lose it in your bag or at night. Seriously, what were manufacturers thinking printing lens caps in black.

Print using a Bright colour so you don't lose it. ABS is best for strength.
If nozzle is 0.4mm, print Z Layer height under 0.2mm. (0.15 recommended)
(z Layer height < 50% of nozzle width to allow grip and prevent extruded plastic falling over the cliff/edge). 100% fill is best
Only Uses about 8 to 13 Grams of plastic at 100%
Screws onto the back of E Mount lenses, (the side facing the camera)

title: Roof or third level deck for DJI F450 Flamewheel

description.text:
This adds a 3rd level to a DJI F450 Flamewheel or equivalent clone and lets you put electronics up above while looking somewhat more cool than a mast.  Alternatively, it just makes a neat looking cover.  
Print it out and then run zip ties through the holes to attach it to the frame.  
Included is the OpenScad design which you can modify as you need to for other models.  
Note that on my Printrbot Simple Metal, I had to flip the design to get it to print - so I had to have the flat top-deck on the bottom and the legs sticking up.  
Edit:  based on feedback, I modified it a bit and made the legs thicker, and the flat platform on top wider.  I updated the photos and added an f450_roof2.stl that has these changes.  I definitely prefer the new version.

It needs to be flipped 180 (top-down, legs up) to print or else you'll need support to print it as-is right-side up.  
I printed mine in PLA on a Printrbot Simple Metal using 3mm layer height and CuraEngine to slice.  It printed in 35 minutes.

comments.text: Printed one over the weekend. Scaled up the Z-Axis a bit to get more height (30% taller). Turned out great. Looks awesome and it's a good support for the GPS/compass chips.

The small mind bending plastic object. This is a basic six piece puzzle made from one type of part. It would appear not to able to be assembled but you can..... This puzzle came from this page. http://www.johnrausch.com/PuzzlingWorld/chap10d.htm If you would like to bake your noodle further have a browse through the whole book: http://www.johnrausch.com/PuzzlingWorld/default.htm It has a significant number of puzzles, many of which could be made on a 3d printer and or a laser cutter. I dare all thingizens to transmogrify a puzzle or three into the thingiverse.

• Edit if you dare
  • Scale to suit
  • Skein
  • Print 6 copies
  • Clean well and file/sand off daggies and warts
  • Go completely insane attempting to assemble
    • To save some of your frustration (and sanity) the following words of wisdom may, or may not be of use. Make 2 sets of 3 left and right handed.
    Slide in on the diagonal.
    With some squish and wiggle. If the above makes no sense, tough :P No hammers were used in the construction of this puzzle.

description.text:
This is the obvious follow-on to my last Thingiverse entry, the LCD Temperature display: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6753 This one has a keypad. Even with that, you can probably squeak in just under $20 for all the parts. CURRENTLY DOES:
  • Temperature Monitoring Screen
  • Scrollable Error/Other Logging Screen
  • SD Card File Selection and PRINT QUEUE
  • Yes, queued up prints from SD Card files... Almost makes me want to put my ABP back on. Not even RepG will do this.
  • Print Queue Management: delete, add, start, stop, abort current (not even RepG will do that! - it just resets the system).
  • Control Menu: Select screens from friendly menu, abort print, reset printer, destroy universe -- Not even RepG can do that!
  • Pause/Resume with BYPASS: the print will pause but you can jog the motors, rehome, and such, then resume right where you left off. Not even RepG will do this.
  • Motor controls, move X,Y,Z,A,B -- even while a print is paused!!
    • WIP WHY:
  • MANY features still to add!
  • Brand new, hardly tested!
  • Firmware .hex file uploaded below is from my machine, with 2 toolheads.
    • I'm verbose by nature so I'm sure I'll have more to say, but I'm mostly busy coding on this right now, so I'll get back to you. YOUTUBE VIDEOS: Initial test: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0prldLWJgzk
    Queuing up a (single) file to print: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mcbtRGPwFbU
    Testing pause + motor override... FAIL!: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lebdaPDFlJk
    -- It /should/ stay paused on the motor menu and let me do what I want, but instead when I go to the motor menu it resumes printing. FUnny enough, the command override does work, you'll see me raise Z a couple times and then it immediately goes back to where it was. :) UPDATE (v2):
    Added queued print functionality, so you can pick a whole bunch of files off the SD card (or the same one a whole bunch of times) and the system will print them one after the other. Does RepG still want you to do this manually by copypasting gcode? UPDATE (v3):
    Added a bunch of features to the print queue, and a menu. Added abort print, reset printer, and destroy universe commands. UPDATE (v4):
    Added motor control menu... needs to be simplified a bit but it all works. This release changes the semantics of the 'pause' control in RepG and elsewhere; now it pauses as soon as it finishes the current movement, instead of immediately. Should be a minor difference, I hope. UPDATE -- noV:
    I think I got myself up and running on github. Let me know if I'm doin' it right. Quite a bit different than my SVN! https://github.com/ScribbleJ

1) Start with the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6753 LCD temperature display. Come back here when you have that working. I'll wait. 2) Get (or make, it's easy) a button grid of at least 3x4. Here's the one I'm using in this build: http://www.sparkfun.com/products/8653 3) Wire it to the pins on your ToM motherboard. How, exactly, you accomplish this is up-to you. I used the same method from the LCD temperature display. Since you're already familiar with that, here's my pin chart for this one: 1 COL2 -> 15 L,4
2 ROW1 -> 17 L,2
3 COL1 -> 19 L,0
4 ROW4 -> 16 L,3
5 COL3 -> 18 L,1
6 ROW3 -> 20 B,7 -> X-MAX B,5
7 ROW2 -> 3 C,4 You should know what's up here, but pin6 and pin7 need some explaining:
  • pin 6 I wanted to connect to 20, B7. But that is the 'debug pin' and sinks the current through an LED, making it not work here. So as I was otherwise out of pins, I stuck it on the unused sensor pin in the X-MAX endstop. I seriously doubt anyone is using X-MAX.
  • pin 7 I pulled out the unused pin3 from my LCD assembly, and stuck pin 7 in there, making it 3 C4 instead.
    • 4) AS ALWAYS it's best if you take my .patch file, merge it with your source tree, edit the configuration file, and compile your own. If anyone needs help with those steps, let me know. You can use my .hex file, but until this project is finalized I probably will be uploading the .hex from my machine, which assumes 2 toolheads ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6632 ) and who knows what else, and means you have to once again wire yours up to the same pins I did! If you are using the .patch and using the same keypad I did, the datasheet for it is here: http://sycelectronica.com.ar/electromecanicos/TECLA-TELEF.pdf 5) USING THE KEYPAD! -- Any UI experts who want to chime in, NOW IS THE TIME I CAN USE YOUR INPUT! 5 = PAUSE/UNPAUSE SYSTEM
    1 = DISPLAY TEMPERATURES
    3 = DISPLAY LOG
  • 2/8 = SCROLL UP/DOWN
    7 = DISPLAY PRINT QUEUE
  • 2/8 = PREV/NEXT FILE
  • 4/6 = STOP/START QUEUE (doesn't stop what's currently printing, just what's next)
    • = DELETE FROM QUEUE (not from SDcard! no worries!)

  • = ADD TO QUEUE (brings up file selector)

    -- FILE SELECTOR
    -- 2 = NEXT FILE (no way to go backwards yet)
    -- 8 = NEXT FILE
    -- 5 or # = ADD TO QUEUE
    -- * = ABORT (back to queue screen)
    9 = DISPLAY MOTOR CONTROL MENU

  • 1/7 = INCREASE/DECREASE MOTION TIME (i.e. 1sec,2sec, etc)
  • */# = DECREASE/INCREASE MOTION LENGTH (i.e. 10mm, 30mm, etc)
  • 4/6 = MOVE X
  • 2/8 = MOVE Y
  • 3/9 = MOVE Z
  • 5 = change 1/7 & */# to modify extrusion speed (IN MM!) - toggle
    0 = DISPLAY MAIN MENU
  • 2 = PREV MENU ITEM
  • 8 = NEXT MENU ITEM
  • 5 or # = SELECT MENU ITEM (there is no confirmation, it will just do it, so be careful!)
    • Main Menu Items:
  • MOTOR MENU - takes you to motor control (same as '9' most places)
  • TEMPERATURE MENU - takes you there (same as '1' most places)
  • FILE QUEUE - takes you there (same as '7' most places)
  • MESSAGE LOG - takes you there (same as '3' most places)
  • ABORT PRINT - Instantly kills the currently-running print, will immediately start on next if there is a queue.
  • RESET PRINTER - Does what it says on the label.
  • DESTROY UNIVERSE - Same. Use caution.

ABOUT THE .STL:
This is the same .scad file from the previous thing, so you can grab it there... only the dimensions are changed.

comments.text: I had a conversation about this today with someone.  While the code I wrote could easily be applied to a cupcake, there are not enough free pins on a cupcake motherboard to drive it, even if I adapted the plans to use half-width comms and less pins, it still wouldn't make it.  The only way to get enough pins on a cupcake motherboard is to use a more expensive serial/i2c keypad and lcd, like Revar's solution, or to mount a separate (arduino) board to control it, which would add maybe $20 cost minimum, and require different software.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
Rocket by JJBTEXAS remix

[UPDATE] I just noticed that both the top and bottom parts will easily fit on the 5.5 x 5.5" Afinia buildplate. This print requires 2 hrs 30 minutes, 60 grams ABS.
And if both are printed together, there is no need for the "sacrificial bar" mentioned below.** ===
This rocket reminded me of some childhood thing... can't recall what... a cartoon.. or a toy.. so I printed one. But it was slightly too tall for Afinia's build volume. Rather than scale it down, I cut it, and made a stash box.
The top fits good and snug.
The box might be worthy of a hinged top, if someone has the inclination to design it. Bottom part took 1 hr 54 minutes, used 45grams ABS with Afinia defaults (0.3mm Z, medium speed with raft).
Top section, 39 minutes 15 grams. Using the default Afinia "support angle" of 30 degrees there was no support to remove from inside the top (lid) or outside the bottom part (except on the very bottom of the rocket). **To get a nice sharp point on the top lid, I used a sacrificial bar (STL included) to occupy the hot extruder between layers and prevent overheating the tip top. Place it near the model on the platform.
(Only required if the top is printed by itself.)

title: Helmet Cam Mount (ARC RAIL, for Sony HDR Series)

description.text:
Sony HDR-AZ1 Action Cam mount
=========
for ARC helmet rail

picture
Ops-Core FAST Base Jump Helmet (Red, Military)
with pre-installed ARC helmet rail
and Sony HDR-AZ1 mounted with printed mount and Wing-loc Adaptor. Parts needed

• Sony Actioncam HDR series
  • compatible waterproof case
  • Printed mount
  • 2 or 3 M4x8 screw and M4x6 insert
    (or equivalent screw & insert for 6mm hole)
  • ARC helmet rail
  • compatible helmet
    (Ops-Core FAST helmet or ACH helmet recommended)
  • Wing-Loc Adapter
  • 1/4 screw
    (standard screw for camera mount. May be included in your camera package.)
    • All HDR actioncam compatible.

• Attach ARC rail onto your helmet.
    if you have rail installed already, skip to 2.
    if you are not familiar with this, it is available at airsoft gear shop.
  • Put your insert into at least two of three holes.
  • Screw Wing-loc adaptor on it.
    make sure that the screw is NOT too long to come out on the other side.
  • Place your camera with waterproof case on, in proper place.
  • Use 1/4 screw to hold the camera.
    Do not screw it too tight or you may break the mount.
    Use a washer if available.
  • Put Wing-loc adaptor on ARC rail on your right side of the helmet.

title: Ultimaker 2 Platform mount for GoPro Timelapse

description.text:
Simple mount for GoPro Housing to film time lapse footage. Allows for install anywhere along the front of the lower platform. I'm using a minimal 3d printed Gopro frame so the whole assembly stays light weight.  Prints in a single piece, has no clearance issues with bottom of ultimaker2 front frame or any potential for camera contact (provided you installed it right!!)  
"Raise platform" in settings to install on bottom platform, (not the heated bed!!!) Needs to be pushed on all the way onto the platform so everything clears correctly, make sure recess on bottom of mount lines up with the front panel on the ultimaker 2 so when the bed lowers, you don't have any terrible noises or broken bits.  
Test the full motion before putting your GoPro in there so you have a reference.  
I'm not an engineer, please don't set your house on fire.  
Designed in tinkercad, STL repaired in netfabb.  
Printed successfully at .1 layer height, .8 shell, 20% infill, 25% support "everywhere."
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N7yHzyFj5CM

author: trooper1

title: Replacement nozzle for Zeepro ZIM filament cartridges

description.text:
So, your Printer messed up your cartridge? No problem:
Just print a new filament outlet yourself.
Cut the cartridge outlet flush and replace it with your new part. This is the Version to glue on with some instant adhesive. I´m working on a version without glueing at all. EDIT: For a glue-free Version, I highly recommend you my refillable cartridge with exchangable beaks...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:718225

My prescious ZIM totally messed up my cartridges due a way-too-hard spring. So I thought: What do I have a 3D Printer for, if I can´t make my own spareparts? That was an easy one... Just open the cartridge and remove the filament and the small O-ring. Then, reassemble the empty cartridge and cut off the whole outlet flush to the case. Open the cartridge again and reinsert the O-ring and the filament. Pull the filament through the new outlet and position the new outlet. Test the filament to go freely before securing the new part with a drop of instant-glue. UPDATE 1:
I just added a second model "EZ-Print" optimized for easier printing by removing all those unnecessary slots.

I've been working with Greg Frost's gear generator.  Getting the gears to mesh requires some math, or trial and error.  As a programmer, I don't like doing either one more than once. :-)
This script lets you specify the axle spacing and gear ratio and get the circular_pitch parameter.  It simplifies fitting gears together.

This is a library.  To use it, include it in your own OpenSCAD creation.  There are two functions you'll need.  The included example_gears module demonstrates their use.
gear_outer_radius lets you compute the meshing radius of a gear, given its parameters.  You'll need this to translate the gears into position.
fit_spur_gears computes the circular pitch for Greg's script.

author: Printoholic

description.text:
I had more or less everything lieing around, so I decided to design this enclosure for the IR LEDs, the raspi and the NoIR cam and built it. It is still not perfect, but everything sits fine and works like a charm.
Information on the parts I used and the code are located unter instructions. 22.02.2015: The walls seem a bit too thin, a piece of mine broke off, now it won't keep closed very well. Improved version incoming! 25.02.2015: I uploaded rev2 files.
Changes:

front got thicker walls (3mm instead of 2mm)
Where the walls get thinner to slide into one another they are now 1.5mm thick instead of the very easy to crack 1mm thick walls
Nut-holder for tripod-mount is now closed by the front when the case is assembled, looks nicer.
Back piece is now only 1.5mm thick instead of 2mm.
Some minor changes
It should now take a bit more time and material to print, but be much more durable and stable.

28.02.2015: Just printed rev2. It prints nicely, everything fits (The IR spotlight fits a bit better, actually), and it is way more stable (and once closed it stays closed, it's actually a bit tricky to reopen it). Not as fragile as rev1. 19.09.2015: Finally took the time to delete the rev1 images, and add some rev2 images, instead!

Please print rev2 front and back, not the old rev1 files! rev2 is improved for better fit of the components and a lot higher overall stability. Parts:

12V PSU (2A or more)
Raspberry A+
NoIR cam
12V -> 5V DC-DC
IR spotlight
I used this one: http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/OTA5ODY0OTk-/Bausaetze_Module/Bausaetze/Infrarot_Scheinwerfer_Bausatz.html
Logic-Level-MOSFET
220R and 10K 1/4W resistor (exact values not very important)

Short explanation:
I used the 12V PSU and connector of my printrbot simple metal, as they were replaced by something more powerful as I added a heated bed.
The connector needs a 8mm hole, so every other type of connector with 8mm external diameter and any other PSU with 12V and 2A or more should work. The 12V -> 5V DC-DC converter was taken out of a phone charger for cars. The IR spotlight made me some trouble, as it is a design-fail. 60mA per LED, while they are designed for 20, max. 30mA. After 5min it nearly desolders itself. That's why I added the MOSFET, which is switched by a GPIO of the raspberry. In that way the spotlight gets only switched on for 1s while the image is being taken. Here is my current shell script: http://pastebin.com/1DtJtZ9s
Warning: Once launched it creates an endless loop and takes a picture every 10s until you force-stop it with ctrl-C or power down the raspberry!
Execute it with sudo in order to work. It will not be able to control the spotlight otherwise.

comments.text: can you tell me what a mosfet you use?? please :-D
comments.author: Fraseco

comments.text: I used an IRLZ34N. It is incredibly overpowered for this application, but it was the only logic-level-FET I had at hand.
comments.author: Fraseco

comments.text: thanks for your fast answer

remixed_from.author: jmne
remixed_from.title: Lasercut tiles for Settlers of Catan

title: Lasercut tiles for Settlers of Catan

description.text: I modified the tileset uploaded by jmne to allow for different kinds of acrylic for each tile type. The result is a nice colourful set of lasercut puzzle-connected tiles for Settlers of Catan.

To use these tiles, first read through the original Thing by jmne. Then verify that the tileset will work with your widths: I measured my acrylics after buying them, and instead of the 3" I expected, they all were 3.03" wide â€” the guides in the .CDR are for this width. If your acrylic has a different width, you will need to edit the .CDR to make sure you still align your tiles inside the acrylic strips. I cut them in two passes: once with raster settings and only the raster layer. To punch through the covering paper and the acrylic, I used 600 dpi, 100% speed and 50% power on a 60W Epilog Helix. Make sure you only print it as a Raster, not as Vector. You may want to increase the power even more, or do several passes â€” I found the etch still somewhat shallow after this. Second pass, print only the vector layer, and with acrylic vector cutting settings. I used 20% speed, 90% power. Once cut, paint the tiles â€” before you remove the covering paper. I used acrylic paint that I diluted with a few splashes of water to make it runny enough to really soak down into the etched acrylic. Dry the pieces overnight, and then peel off the covering paper. It will bring the acrylic paint with it as you pull it off. For the small specks in the middle of the design, I have found that using finger nails is optimal. I tried a few design tricks that didn't quite pan out in this. I made the Rocks out of a dark gray acrylic, and painted on black, as the dark areas in the original design correspond to shadows in the picture. It may be significantly better if you invert the images first, and then paint over with white, but I haven't tried that yet. Furthermore, some of the tiles have really thin design elements â€” these may not quite come out cleanly. Material consumption:
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for ports
3" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for desert
6" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for circlets
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for brick tiles
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for wheat tiles
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for forest tiles
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for ore tiles
10" x 3" 1/8" Acrylic for sheep tiles Also, white and black acrylic paint. Final words:
Settlers of Catan is a fantastic game. This will not give you a complete game set. You should buy the game independently.

description.text:
Hier habe ich das originale Gehäuse leicht verändert, sodaß mein Piund mein Touch da reinpassen.  
Ich hab den Ausschnitt für das Bild perfekt angepasst, sowie die Höhe des Oberteils vergrößert, da das Original zu niedrig war.  
Auch habe ich eine Nase des Oberteils entfernt und dafür ins Unbterteil eine reingemacht, damit sich das Gehäuse im geschlossenen Zustand nicht mehr aufschieben kann.  
Vermutlich ein kleiner Gedankenfehler des Urhebers :)  
Auch habe ich die Auflagen für das Display vergrößert, da bei mir der Bildschirm immer daneben hing bzw. beim Bedienen runterrutschte.  
Ansonsten ist es original geblieben.  
Viel Spaß damit.
